The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 includes provisions for improved coordination of export promotion programs and facilitation of export opportunities for small businesses. It consolidates duplicative export promotion activities, clarifies roles of committee members, and enhances Export.gov as a single window for export information. Key sections include definitions, promotion of exporting, small business export matchmaking pilot program, export control education, inter-agency task force on export financing, and availability of State resource guides on Export.gov. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to improve coordination of export promotion activities, including consolidating offices and utilizing electronic databases. The Act also requires detailed listings of trade missions and fairs to better serve US businesses. The Secretary of Commerce must make information on trade missions available to the public. The Secretary of Commerce is required to make information on Federal and State-led trade missions, trade fairs, and related activities available on Export.gov or a successor website. SEC. 102. CLARIFICATION OF ROLES OF MEMBERS OF TRADE PROMOTION COORDINATING COMMITTEE. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of departments or agencies in export promotion and financing activities. This includes identifying the role, goals, and objectives of each department or agency, as well as the rationale for measuring and reporting on those goals and objectives. Congress is also included in the reporting requirements. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of departments or agencies in export promotion and financing activities. This includes identifying the role, goals, and objectives of each department or agency, as well as recommendations from the Comptroller General of the United States related to coordination of the TPCC and its members. Additionally, the United States National Tourism Organization is replaced by the United States Travel Association. SEC. 103 amends the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 to include a representative of state agencies on the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. SEC. 104 requires reports to Congress regarding the activities of the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. Section 2312(f) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to require annual reports to Congress by the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee (TPCC) and the Inspector General of the Department of Commerce regarding strategic plans, implementation of export promotion activities, and interagency working groups on energy. The TPCC must provide an annual report to appropriate congressional committees by March 30 on its successful performance of duties and implementation of the strategic plan. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce must consult with other federal agencies' inspectors general in preparing the report. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in Congress. The TPCC must report annually to specific congressional committees on its performance and strategic plan implementation. These committees include those from the Senate and the House of Representatives. SEC. 105. REPORT ON IMPROVEMENTS TO EXPORT.GOV AS A SINGLE WINDOW FOR EXPORT INFORMATION. The Director of International Trade of the Small Business Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment, with recommendations for enhancing Export.gov as a comprehensive resource for exporters. The report should also propose making Export.gov a single website for all information required by the Federal Government for exporting articles from the United States, after consulting with small business concerns and relevant entities. The President's Export Council, State agencies, district export councils, and trade associations are involved in export promotion and financing. SEC. 106 of the Act requires a report on creating a single website for exporters to comply with US export control laws. The report will be submitted to specific congressional committees. TITLE II--FACILITATION OF EXPORT OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES

SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS.
- Defines terms like "Administration," "Administrator," "region of the Administration," and "small business concern."

SEC. 202. PROMOTION OF EXPORTING.
- Amends Section 22(c)(11) of the Small Business Act to include promoting exporting as a business development opportunity for small business concerns.

SEC. 203. SMALL BUSINESS EXPORT MATCHMAKING PILOT PROGRAM. The Administrator will establish a pilot program for matchmaking events to connect small businesses with potential foreign buyers. At least one event will be held in each region annually, and events may be coordinated with outreach events. The program authority will end on September 30, 2015. SEC. 204 amends the Small Business Act to prioritize educating small businesses on Federal export control regulations. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing to review and improve Federal export finance programs. SEC. 206 ensures the availability of State resource guides on export.gov. SEC. 206 mandates the Secretary of Commerce to provide State resource guides on Export.gov, detailing export promotion and financing resources by State.
